Comments: English essayist, poet, playwright and politician (1672–1719).[1]
Chief Rabbi of Great Britain 1845–1890
Long-term rented Valence House with her brother Aymer de Valence, 2nd Earl of Pembroke in the fourteenth century on the north side of the road
Bought a house called St Margaret's near the site of the road, which later would give its name to the area.[2]

Named after: Frederick, Duke of York and Albany
Comments: Younger brother of George IV, in whose reign the street was built
Previous owner of the property on which the road was built in 1683-4
Consort of Queen Victoria. The Embankment was built between 1866 and 1869, under the direction of Joseph Bazalgette
Actor and founder of Dulwich College, near the north end of the road, in whose chapel he is now buried.[3]
Actress and singer born in the local area.
Lived at Argyll Lodge, a former house on Campden Hill nearby.[4]

Road: Attlee Road, Ayles Road, Bevin Road, Bondfield Avenue, Keir Hardie Way, Morrison Road and Webbs Road
Named after: Clement Attlee, Walter Ayles, Ernest Bevin, Margaret Bondfield, Keir Hardie, Herbert Morrison, Sidney Webb and Beatrice Webb
Comments: Cluster of short roads in Yeading originally formed of social housing named after Labour politicians. Attlee: Labour Party leader (1935-1955) and Prime Minister (1945-1951). Ayles: Labour MP for Southall (1945-1950); then for Hayes and Harlington (1950-1953). Bevin: Foreign Secretary (1945-1951). Bondfield: MP, trades unionist and women's rights activist. Hardie: First Labour MP Morrison: Transport Secretary (1929-1931), Home Secretary (1940-1945) and Deputy Prime Minister (1945-1951). Webbs: prominent social reformers.[5]
Courtier to King Charles II, who lived in nearby St James's Palace[6]
Builder who laid the street out in the 18th century
Founded a boy's orphanage in Stepney Causeway adjoining in 1870.
Architect who designed Dulwich Park, to which the road leads to[7]
Theatrical producer and manager of the Old Vic Theatre on the road. In the Waterloo part of Lambeth. Previously Oakley Street.
Beauchamp Place, on the site of the road, was also a 16th-century mansion of the Seymour family, whose titles included Viscount Beauchamp[8]
French sailor and Arctic explorer who disappeared, and has a memorial in Greenwich[9]
Son of King Edward III
Tightrope walker and acrobat, who lived and died at nearby Niagara House in Northfields. Commemorates Niagara Falls where Blondin performed his most famous tightrope walk in 1859.
Jamaican singer-songwriter and musician, one of the most widely known performers of reggae music. Brixton.[10]

Named after: Henry St John, 1st Viscount St John (also known as Viscount Bolingbroke)
Comments: Owner of the land on which the road was later built, and buried in St Mary's Church, Battersea[11]
Property developer of Bond Street, Dover Street and Albemarle Street, from 1683
The Pleydell-Bouveries, Earls of Radnor, were landlords of this area.[12]

Road: Browning Close, Robert Close and Elizabeth Close
Named after: Robert Browning and Elizabeth Barrett Browning
Comments: Poet who lived in Little Venice, near the site of the road. Elizabeth was one of the most prominent English poets of the Victorian era and his wife.[13]
The road is situated near the south end of Thames Tunnel, which the engineer Brunel built.

Road: Burlington Lane, Burlington Road and Burlington Gardens
Comments: Builder of Chiswick House, in its park adjacent to the road.[14]

Road: Bowen Road, Butler Road, Drury Road, Vaughan Road, Sumner Road, Heath Road
Named after: Headmasters and teachers of Harrow School
Comments: Cluster of streets named after teachers and headmasters of school: Edward Ernest Bowen (c.1885-1901) - author of the Harrow school song, Forty Years On Montagu Butler: (1859–1885)[15] Charles Vaughan: (1845–1859) Joseph Drury (1785–1805) Benjamin Heath (1771–1785) Robert Carey Sumner (1760–1771)
Leader of a popular revolt against the government in 1450, which took place on Blackheath, near where the road now stands.
The road is built on land acquired by Charles Cadogan, 2nd Baron Cadogan on his marriage to Sir Hans Sloane's daughter.

Road: Camden Town, Camden Street, Road, High Street Camden, Bayham Street and Pratt Street
Comments: Owner of the land on which the road and much of the surviving development was built in 1791. The forerunner districts, e.g. St Pancras are little-used.[16][17]

Road: Canning Road, Clyde Road, Elgin Road /ɛlɡɪn/, Havelock Road and Outram Road
Named after: Charles Canning, 1st Earl Canning, Colin Campbell, 1st Baron Clyde, James Bruce, 8th Earl of Elgin, Henry Havelock and Sir James Outram, 1st Baronet
Comments: Group of five roads built on the site of the East India Company Military Seminary by the British Land Company, and named after prominent figures in the history of British India. Canning: statesman and Governor-General of India during the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Clyde, Havelock and Outram: all generals in India during the same rebellion. Elgin: Governor-General of India 1862-3.

Formerly Burton Crescent after its developer, James Burton. Renamed after social reformer who campaigned for universal suffrage, vote by ballot, annual parliaments and the abolition of slavery. He lived and died at No. 37, and a 21st-century erected sculpture nearby[18]
English merchant, diplomat, writer and responsible for the introduction of the printing press to England; the first such press was established in 1476 in Westminster, close to the present road.[19]
Lived at Canons Park, to the north of the road buried in the parish at St Lawrence's church, Whitchurch, Little Stanmore.

Road: Charles II Street (Charles the second Street)

Comments: Married to King George III in 1761; the street was formed in 1763
Lived and died at Hayes Place, a former house on whose estate the road was built[20]
One of the titles of George IV before he became king in 1820. The terrace was constructed in 1825[21]
Both streets are named after houses called Chesterfield House, where the author lived.[22]
Owned the manor of Chelsea until 1712.[23]

Road: Chichele Road, Willesden and Chicheley Street, Lambeth
Comments: 15th-century Archbishop of Canterbury who founded All Souls College, Oxford who owned much of Willesden. Lambeth Palace adjoins the latter site, the arch-episcopal palace in London.[13]
Opened the street in 1828, when she was Duchess of Clarence[24]
Lord Privy Seal at the time the road was built.[25]
Owner of the estate at the time of the layout of the road[26]
Secretary to Charles II, who owned a house near the street.
Owned the land on which the road was later built.[27]
Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland who once owned a house there, son of English military and political leader Oliver Cromwell [28][29]
Younger brother of King George IV at the time of the terrace's construction, 1826.
Curzon was a family name; George Howe was the ground landlord[30]

Named after: Czar Peter the Great of Russia
Comments: Lived at Sayes Court, a former house nearby, in 1698 while studying shipbuilding at Deptford.[31]

Endowed (to charitable trust) Emmanuel Almshouses near-adjoining. Although now demolished,[32] their legacy continues in the three schools, Westminster City School, Grey Coat Hospital and Emanuel School.
First Mayor of Metropolitan Borough of Southwark.[13]
Dean of Westminster Abbey from 1881.
Sometime canon of Westminster Abbey.
Dean of Westminster Abbey from 1911
Well-known author of Robinson Crusoe, who lived in a house at the north end of the road near its junction with Stoke Newington Church Street[33]
Lord Chief Justice between 1832 and 1850. One of several streets on the estate named after lawyers.[34]
With Joseph Toms, founded the former shop of Derry & Toms, near the north end of the street.[35]

Road: Devonshire Road, Cavendish Road, Devonshire Gardens, Devonshire Place, Devonshire Street, Duke Road and Duke's Avenue
Comments: Owners of Chiswick House, on whose large estate the roads were built. Re-built in 1811 by the 6th Duke)[14]
Well-known English author who reputedly crossed Tooting Bec Common near the site of the road to visit Hester Thrale
Famed for finishing first in the marathon 1908 London summer Olympics, but being disqualified for receiving assistance.

Road: Dowding Road, Gossage Road, Keith Park Road, Portal Close, Saunders Road and Tedder Close
Named after: Hugh Dowding, Leslie Gossage, Keith Park, Charles Portal, Hugh Saunders and Arthur Tedder
Comments: Cluster of streets built near the site of the former RAF Uxbridge, and all named after air marshals in the Second World War. Dowding: leader of the RAF during the Battle of Britain. Gossage: Inspector-General of the RAF and Air Member for Personnel. Park: leader of No. 11 Group RAF, which was coordinated nearby, in what is now the Battle of Britain Bunker. Portal: Chief of the Air Staff. Saunders: Chief of Staff for the Royal New Zealand Air Force. Tedder: Air Officer Commanding RAF Middle East Command.
Landlord of the area when the street was built in 1792-1810[37]
Built by and named after Downing
Knight of the Garter in Queen Elizabeth's reign. Owned land on site.

Named after: Lady Georgiana Russell, wife of John Russell, 6th Duke of Bedford
Comments: Lived at Argyll Lodge, a former house on Campden Hill, near the location of the road.[4]
The duke enclosed nearby Greenwich Park. A continuation of the road northwards leads to the Royal Observatory, Greenwich built on the site of Duke Humphrey's Tower

Road: Duke of Wellington Place, Belgravia and Wellington Road, St John's Wood
Comments: The duke lived at Apsley House near the former street, and there is an equestrian statue of him nearby. The latter road was developed from about 1816, following Wellington's victory at the Battle of Waterloo. Many other examples of the duke's name and title (Wellesley and Wellington) are across the capital, less well connected.[24]

Road: Elizabeth Way, Queens Avenue, Seymour Gardens /siːmɔːr/ and Parr Way
Named after: Elizabeth I of England and Catherine Parr
Comments: Elizabeth spent part of her childhood at Hanworth Manor close nearby and sometimes stayed there during her reign[38] The latter two roads reflect the third and sixth wives of King Henry VIII. Catherine inherited the manor from 1544 until her death in 1548[38]</ref>
Lived in exile at nearby Camden Place from 1871 to 1881.[39]
English writer and essayist who lived at Sayes Court, a former house in Deptford near the street.[31]
Lived at Sutton Court, a former house that stood at the east end of the road. Chiswick.[14]
Flowers was the designer of the Colossus computer and worked at the Post Office Research Station adjacent to the road.
One of the Huguenot refugees who settled in the area near the street in the 18th century[40]
Wealthy builder.[41]
Painter, buried in St Anne's Church, Kew.[42]

A Sir Richard Garth became the owner and Lord of the Manor of Morden just after the Dissolution of the Monasteries and maintained their connection with the parish for the next four centuries, until the manor was sold by another Sir Richard Garth in 1872.[43]
General and conqueror of Quebec, who is buried in St Alfege's Church, Greenwich and has a memorial in Greenwich Park. He lived in a house called Macartney House near the road.[22]

Took its name from a former pub called the George and Dragon which stood in Croydon, and named after the saint (not from a former church dedicated to the saint). The present George pub in Croydon is its successor[44]
Main street of Richmond. Took current name in king's honour 1769. Formerly known as Richmond High Street.[42]
The road was built shortly before the Second World War and named in memory of the monarch, who died in 1936. Between Hatch End and Harrow.

Named after: Maria, Duchess of Gloucester and Edinburgh
Comments: Formerly called Hogmore Lane; renamed in 1826 after the duchess who built a house in the road in 1805, and now demolished
One time vicar of St. John's Church in Paddington.
Goodge was a speculative builder of the houses which form the street in the late 18th century.[45]
Wife of the 4th Duke of Bedford, who supervised the laying of the street.
Founded the Grahame-White Aviation Company near the site of the road in 1911[46]
Created in 1845 and named for a notable sixteenth century city financier
Statesman; Prime Minister; the President of the Foundling Hospital, which originally stood in the street[47]
English historian[48]
Banker who lived at Hayes Place, a former house on whose estate the road was later built.[20]

Road: Hamilton Road, Hardy Road and Nelson Road
Named after: Nelson, (Admiral) Horatio and those most famously connected to him.
Comments: Consecutive streets named after Admiral Nelson (Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson) who all as parts of Merton Place. Emma: his mistress and prominent society model and courtier. Hardy: Thomas Hardy under his command as Flag Captain of HMS Victory.
Well-known German composer who was employed by the Duke of Chandos at Canons Park and reputedly played on the organ of St Lawrence's church nearby. The road was built on part of the estate[49]

Named after: Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer
Comments: Was the 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer and had one son, Edward Harley

Road: Harrington Road, Harrington Gardens, Stanhope Gardens, Petersham Lane, Petersham Mews and Petersham Place
Comments: Owned the area on which the road was later built. The family continued to own it until 1957.[50]
Most of estate leased to Hatton by Elizabeth I in 1581, following a vacancy in the position of Bishop of Ely, whom she appointed. Holborn.
Location of a social club run by philanthropist Henriques
Painter, who is buried in the parish church, and whose house, now a museum, is in the road. Chiswick.

Road: Holland: Road, Park Avenue and Villas Road
Comments: First owner of Holland House and Holland Park, to the east of the road.
Founder and owner of market. Co-source of Hungerford Bridge, arguably a street.
The road in Charlton within former estate of Charlton House with features by or in the style of Jones.[51]
In London's Theatreland. Named after the first actor to be knighted[52]
First World War sailor boy and recipient of the Victoria Cross, who grew up here: Little ILford, East Ham.

Named after: Henry Jermyn, 1st Earl of St Albans
Comments: Developed much of St. James's around the year 1667
Benefactor of Southgate, who lived nearby in The Bourne[53]
Town clerk of the City of London in the fifteenth century, and founder of the City of London School[54]
Abbot of the monastery of Westminster at the time of Henry VIII
Minister of Woolwich Baptist Tabernacle, now Woolwich Central Baptist Church, who gave generously to the local poor[55]
Writer who lived in the road, and whose house is now a museum. The road was formerly called John Street
Earl buried with his mistress in the Kilmorey Mausoleum, near the road.
Originally called Creeksmouth Lane; renamed in 1902 to commemorate the king's coronation.[56]
The avenue was made to commemorate the king's coronation in 1937[57]
Bishop of London who gave generously to the poor of Fulham in 1620[58]

Road: King William Walk (and King William Street, City of London and others)
Comments: His memorial is in the street near the National Maritime Museum. The City example is one of many — merely built in his reign.
Formerly private road used by the king to travel to Kew Palace
Opened the street in 1905.
Lived at Kneller Hall in the road, now the Royal Military School of Music, Whitton, Twickenham.[59]
Hungarian national hero who lived in London in the 1850s. Greenwich.

Road: Ladbroke Grove, Road, Terrace, Square, Gardens, Walk and Crescent
Comments: Developed the North Kensington area around 1840.[60]
British politician (MP 1910-1912, 1922-1940) and social reformer who led the Labour Party from 1932 to 1935. Blackwall (ex.-Poplar)

Road: Lansdowne Road, Lansdowne Crescent and Lansdowne Rise
Comments: Home Secretary and later Chancellor of the Exchequer at the time the road was built.[25]

Road: Latimer Road, Kensington, Latymer Road, Edmonton and Latymer Way, Edmonton
Comments: Clerk at the Court of Wards and Liveries who bequeathed the land on which Latimer Road was later built to help fund Latymer Upper School, which he founded. The school's playing fields are situated west of the road. Originally it ran past the tube station of the same name; but after it was split by the Westway flyover, the south part was renamed Freston Road after the village in Suffolk associated with Latymer.[61] The roads in Edmonton are located near The Latymer School, also founded by Edward Latymer
Archbishop of Canterbury (1633-1645) who lived at Croydon Palace
English writer born in Southgate
Lillie first laid out the easternmost section of the road across his North End Hermitage estate in 1826.[62]
Swedish singer, who entertained the people of Sutton in 1847 with her singing.

Named after: Robert Banks Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool
Comments: The street was built in 1829 and named after the former Prime Minister, who had died the previous year[63]
William Lowther, 2nd Earl of Lonsdale bought the land in 1846, on which the roads were later built[64]

Road: Lyndhurst Grove, Lyndhurst Way and Lyndhurst Square
Comments: Lawyer and politician, three times Lord Chancellor of Great Britain.[34]
Married to Lady Ermyntrude Sackville Russell, daughter of Francis Russell, 9th Duke of Bedford who owned much of the surrounding area.

The street was originally called Selous Street, after Frederick Selous, a game hunter in South Africa who was born in the area. The street in the 1960s became the base of the Anti-Apartheid Movement and in 1985 it was renamed in honour of the then imprisoned ANC leader, who nine years later would become South Africa's first democratically elected president.[65]
Last king of Portugal, home: nearby demolished Fulwell Park House from 1910 (the year of the Portuguese Revolution) until death, 1932. Manoel is the Portuguese spelling.[66]

Road: Matthew Parker Street and Parker Road
Comments: Archbishop of Canterbury from 1559 until 1575.
Carpenter, later esquire, who developed it in the 1720s and 1730s.[67]
The road was built on the estate of the Powell-Cotton family, one of which, Major Percy Powell-Cotton, was given permission by Emperor Menelik to hunt in Ethiopia in 1900.[68]
Carpenter and builder who in 1830, at the time of the name change, owned the building lease of the street at the time. The street was previously known as Grub Street[69]

Road: Mornington Crescent, Place, Street and Terrace
Comments: His daughter Anne married Henry Fitzroy, brother of the 1st Baron Southampton, on whose estate the road was built.[70]

Named after: Edward Harley, 2nd Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer
Comments: Developer of Cavendish Square in London, and the streets around it, from 1715. Amongst his titles were Earl of Oxford and Mortimer, and Baron Harley of Wigmore Castle[71]
Owned the land on which road was later built
Scientist and mathematician
The Avenue was built in the 1870s on the site of Northumberland House, the redundant, demolished home of the Duke of Northumberland (see Syon House and Alnwick Castle).

Road: Elizabeth Way, Queens Avenue, Seymour Gardens and Parr Way
Named after: Elizabeth I of England and Catherine Parr
Comments: Elizabeth spent part of her childhood at Hanworth Manor close nearby and sometimes stayed there during her reign[38] The latter two roads reflect the third and sixth wives of King Henry VIII. Catherine inherited the manor from 1544 until her death in 1548[38]</ref>

The so-called river, a surface level aqueduct, adjoins and is back-named after Hugh Percy, 1st Duke of Northumberland and his successors who maintained the canal, his wife's direct forebear re-inherited much of the land of the borough in 1594. The family continues to own Syon House.

Named after: Louis Philippe I, previously Duke of Orleans
Comments: French royal, later king, who lived in exile at Orleans House near the road[72]
Owned the land on which the roads were later built, the Richmond one first (1761-1778), the Hampton ones in the borough later.[42]

Named after: Edward Harley, 2nd Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer
Comments: Developer of Cavendish Square in London, and the streets around it, from 1715[71]
Archbishop of Canterbury (1559-1575) who lived at Croydon Palace

Road: Pelham Crescent, Pelham Place and Pelham Street
Comments: A former trustee of the Smith's Charity Estate, on which the road was built.[73]
Lord Mayor of London in 1611, and a member of the Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths, on whose estate the road was built[73]
1923 renaming; Pepys lived there during the Great Fire of London.[74]
Family owned the undeveloped estate. Limehouse.[75]
Accountant and public servant who served as Sheriff of the County of London in 1927[76]
The Pleydell-Bouveries, Earls of Radnor, were landlords of this area.[77]
Poet who had built the demolished Pope's Villa and surviving Pope's Grotto, and is buried in St Mary's Church, Twickenham.
Margaret Bentinck, Duchess of Portland, the daughter of Edward Harley, 2nd Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer inherited his land and property and married into the Portland family[71]
Rented nearby Broomfield House in 1816.[78]
Chairman of the company which built the canal basin which lies just to the north
Originally called Albert Road; renamed after the Prince Consort of Queen Victoria in 1938

Named after: Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn
Comments: Son of Queen Victoria who opened a home for sailor's daughters in the area in 1869[79]
Part of Albertopolis
The road was built on the estate of Charlton House, whose original owner, Adam Newton, was the Prince's tutor.[51]
Lived in exile at nearby Camden Place from 1871 until his death in 1879.[39]
Queen of England, Scotland and Ireland from 1702, and after the Act of Union, Queen of Great Britain until 1714
Wife of George IV, who lived and died in nearby Brandenburg House
The queen founded Kingston Grammar School at Lovekyn Chapel, which is at the south end of the street (the school's main buildings are opposite)[80]
The queen's friend, Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester, lived in Stoke Newington.[24]
named Queen's Road in honour of Victoria, who had been born at nearby Kensington Palace. Later renamed.
One Captain Rathbone was the builder of the road and properties thereon, from about 1718[45]
Named c. 1811, when George IV was Prince regent
Built the road in about 1695, when Chief Ranger of Greenwich Park, to restore communication between Greenwich and Woolwich[81]
First Chairman of the London County Council, who opened the road in 1892[82]
One of Roy's two cannons he used to map Middlesex is in the road in Hampton Hill.[83]
Saint and Bishop of London who founded Barking Abbey to the west of the road
Wife of the Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington, architect and developer.[84]
Gave his name to the Savoy Palace, which stood on the site of the road
Owned, and lived near, the land on which the road was later built; contributed to the founding of nearby church St John the Divine, Richmond.

Shaftesbury was an active philanthropist, and as a Member of Parliament he was responsible for several reforming acts designed to alleviate the suffering of the poor. The new Avenue replaced slum housing, and was finished in the year of his death, 1886.
Archbishop of Canterbury (1663-1677) who lived at Croydon Palace, and is buried in Croydon Minster
Aviation pioneer who set up a factory near the east end of the road, where his earliest aircraft were made[85]
Landowner.

Named after: Edward Stanley, 2nd Baron Stanley of Alderley
Comments: President of the Board of Trade at the time the road was built.[25]
South African anti-apartheid activist
Lessee in 1540 of the pastures on which the road was built.[86]
Judge and politician, buried in West Norwood Cemetery, south of the street.[34]
Composer and hymn-writer whose name is engraved on the façade of the nearby former building of the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, which stood here until 1977[87]
Wife of Dr Johnson, who is buried in the nearby Bromley Parish Church[88]
Lawyer, writer and statesman executed in the nearby Tower of London, who has a memorial plaque in the street[89]
Chief banker of England in the reign of Queen Elizabeth
World boxing champion of 1810, who lived and died in Woolwich, where the road is located

King of Norway who fought with Æthelred the Unready against the Danes allegedly in what became the parish of St Olave's, Southwark. He was canonised and the name was corrupted from St Olaf to Tooley. The church was demolished in 1926 and St Olaf House, with a stone relief of him stands on the site.[90][91]

Road: Tyers Street, Jonathan Street and Tyers Walk
Comments: The road passes Vauxhall Gardens. Tyers was the owner in the eighteenth century.[92]
Builder of Wanstead Park, a former house whose estate extended southwards to the location of the road[93]
Actress and singer born in the local area.
A family name of the area's owners at the time of its construction, the Earls of Oxford[94]

Separated by Parliament Square from the embankment, the road bisects the mid-west neighbourhood of Westminster is sometimes called Victoria after its station particularly towards Buckingham Palace and less so toward the south where it is Belgravia. Many other examples of the monarch's name are across the capital, less well connected.
The Street was built in the 1670s on the site of York House, Villiers' Mansion
Wife of the 7th Earl Waldegrave who lived at Strawberry Hill House in the 19th century in the road. Twickenham.[95]
Prominent local family who owned Arnos Grove (now Southgate Beaumont) on nearby Cannon Hill. The street is located near the better known Arnos Grove tube station[96]
Architect of several buildings on the street
Wife of Charles FitzRoy, 1st Baron Southampton, the land owner responsible for the development of the area[45] - see Fitzroy Square
Rebel who launched the Peasants' Revolt in 1381
Bishop of Peterborough (1707), and previously rector of the nearly St Botolph's Aldgate
Builder of Whitefield's Tabernacle, in the vicinity, in 1756[45]
Archbishop of Canterbury (1583-1604) who lived at Croydon Palace, and is buried in Croydon Minster.
First Mayor of Richmond, who bought a building adjacent to the road which became the town hall
British politician, a philanthropist and a leader of the movement to abolish the slave trade
A prominent local politician, who was Mayor of Woolwich three times
Artist who spent his childhood at the nearby Water House, which is now the William Morris Gallery

Road: Wilton Crescent, Place, Row and Terrace
Comments: Second son of Robert Grosvenor, 1st Marquess of Westminster; the road forms part of the Grosvenor estate.
18th-century actress who performed in Teddington, near where the road is located, and buried in Teddington parish church[97]
The road was built on the grounds of a former house said to have been occupied by Wren[98]
Developer of the area, including Kensington Square
